page.title: First Nations Pandemic Response
page.description: The page for The Meeting House First Nations Pandemic Response in partnership with MCC Canada.

image1.alt: Amanda speaking to a group at the Timmins Native Friendship Centre.

content.text1: Thank you for your overwhelming generosity to the First Nations Pandemic Response. Together, we raised $75,000!

The Mushkegowuk Tribal Council, Windigo First Nations Council, and Mennonite Central Committee (MCC), have determined the items in the sanitary kits and will distribute them to the most vulnerable households among 14 remote First Nations communities in northern Ontario and three Indigenous organizations in Timmins. Our partners estimate that over 15,000 people will benefit from this initiative.

image1.alt: Lyndsay Mollins Koene, an MCC employee, with a First Nations woman.

content.text1: Lack of access to clean water, overcrowded households, and limited medical care have made remote First Nations communities especially vulnerable to COVID-19. By donating $10 to cover the cost of a sanitary kit, you're partnering with First Nations leaders so that they can protect and equip their communities.

image1.alt: An MCC employee packs sanitary items into a plane before delivery.

content.text1: As a church, we’ve been exploring what it means to work toward reconciliation between First Nations and settler communities. This season, we want to pursue reconciliation by partnering with First Nations leaders to ensure that vulnerable families have access to sanitary items.

image1.alt: A woman from Attawapiskat First Nation stands in front of a wood pile.
A pile of hand-sewn face masks, including one with an eagle on the front.
Timmins City Counselor presenting on Indigenous bundles.

list.question: Can I only give online?
answer: Yes. Donations are made to Mennonite Central Committee directly and can be received online through the giving portal above.

list.question: Will I receive a tax receipt?
answer: Yes. Donations over $10 will be issued a tax receipt by Mennonite Central Committee. Note that you will not receive a tax receipt from The Meeting House.

list.question: Which First Nations communities will receive the kits?
answer: Mushkegowuk Tribal Council (7): Weenisk, Attawapiskat, Fort Albany, Kashechewan, Moose Cree, Mocreebec First Nations, and the town of Moosonee.
Windigo First Nations Council (7): Bearskin Lake, Cat Lake, Koocheching, North Caribou, Sachigo, Slate Falls, and Whitewater First Nations.
Timmins Urban Organizations: Missiway Health Centre, the Timmins Native Friendship Centre, and the MCC Indigenous Neighbours office.

list.question: What are the items in the kits?
answer: MCC will bulk purchase the items in the kit (please do not purchase them yourselves). The kits will include a hand towel, a face cloth, hand sanitizer, a face mask, a laundry soap bar, and two bars of soap.

list.question: Can I purchase the items in the kit myself?
answer: No. We want to play our part in limiting the spread of COVID-19, which is why we don’t want to encourage our community to leave their homes to purchase the kits. Additionally, by bulk ordering items in the kits, our partners will be able to distribute the kits sooner.

list.question: What happens if we surpass our goal?
answer: This would be awesome! Any additional funds would be given to MCC’s Indigenous Neighbours program to be used to address the ongoing needs of their First Nations communities in Ontario.

list.question: What is the Mushkegowuk Tribal Council & Windigo First Nations Council?
answer: The Mushkegowuk Tribal Council & Windigo First Nations Council are non-profit regional chiefs' councils representing two clusters of remote First Nations communities in northern Ontario, Canada. Each council provides advisory services and program delivery to its member nations, including oversight in health care within their affiliated First Nations communities.

list.question: Why partner with MCC?
answer: We are proud to be partnering with Mennonite Central Committee as they come alongside locally directed projects around the globe and here in Canada. MCC also has a strong relationship with many First Nations communities in Ontario and has developed a positive reputation among these communities.

MCC Canada has demonstrated commitment to a high level of transparency, accountability, and integrity. They are a member of the Canadian Council of Christian Charities (CCCC) and the Better Business Bureau, which have standards for fundraising as well as managing and reporting finances. In 2019, MCC was listed on Charity Intelligence Canada’s Top 10 International Impact Charities.
